most_divergent.statement: CBD, erastin, and DIDS engage three structurally and mechanistically distinct VDAC1 sites — lipid-protein interface (CBD), interior barrel wall β14-19 (erastin), and pore vestibule lysines (DIDS) — with no significant competitive overlap.

VDAC2's 11-residue N-terminal extension sterically remodels the helix-groove pocket, reducing CBD-type ligand affinity by ≥10-fold and enabling VDAC1-selective design without relying solely on cofactor competition.

At clinical concentrations (1–10 μM), CBD achieves only ~30–50% VDAC1 occupancy (Kd = 11 μM), producing graded gating modulation rather than channel ablation — this partial occupancy is pharmacologically essential for tolerability.

Barrel-wall ligands (erastin class) produce near-binary conductance block (Hill coefficient ≥1.5, steep dose-response), while helix-site ligands (CBD class) produce graded allosteric modulation (Hill coefficient ~1, shallow dose-response), representing pharmacologically distinct classes.

1**: CBD, erastin, and DIDS bind three distinct VDAC1 sites: CBD at the lipid-protein interface near the N-term helix, erastin in the barrel wall (β14–19), and DIDS covalently at pore-facing lysines (K12/K20). *TYPE*: 1 *CONFIDENCE*: 0.85 *MECHANISM*: CBD’s lipophilicity (logP 6.3) drives partitioning into membrane-adjacent grooves; erastin’s sulfonamide engages polar barrel residues (E73/R15); DIDS’s isothiocyanates react with solvent-accessible lysines. *FALSIFIABLE BY*: Cryo-EM showing CBD in the barrel lumen or erastin at the N-term; mutagenesis (K12A/K20A) abolishing DIDS binding without affecting erastin.

2**: VDAC2’s +11aa N-terminal extension sterically occludes VDAC1-like CBD/erastin sites, enabling >10-fold VDAC1 selectivity at 1–11 μM. *TYPE*: 1 *CONFIDENCE*: 0.75 *MECHANISM*: The extended N-term in VDAC2 (unstructured/helical) shields the gating domain, reducing ligand access vs. VDAC1’s compact helix. *FALSIFIABLE BY*: Chimeric VDAC1/2 constructs (VDAC1 + VDAC2 N-term) showing reduced CBD affinity; cryo-EM of VDAC2 with CBD bound.

3**: N-term helix ligands (e.g., CBD) act as allosteric gating modulators (EC50 ~11 μM), while barrel ligands (erastin/DIDS) act as pore blockers (Ki <1 μM). *TYPE*: 1 *CONFIDENCE*: 0.70 *MECHANISM*: Hel
CBD, erastin, DIDS bind distinct VDAC1 sites: CBD at lipid-facing N-helix groove (residues 1-25/β1-2), erastin in barrel lumen (β14-19, E73

VDAC1 ligand binding sites define two distinct pharmacological classes: (1) N-terminal helix binders (e.g., CBD) are allosteric modulators of voltage-gating, and (2) Barrel-occluding ligands (e.g., erastin, DIDS) are direct conductance blockers.
The VDAC2 N-terminal extension sterically hinders the VDAC1-like CBD binding pocket, reducing CBD affinity by at least an order of magnitude (predicted VDAC2 Kd > 100 μM).
